answers.text: the center of the tongue is raised during and after the articulation of the consonant
with the tip of the tongue against the teeth rather than against the alveolar ridge

qas.question: G is considered marginal but not considered what?

plausible_answers.text: "это ткёт" ([ˈɛtə tkʲɵt], 'it weaves')/"этот кот" ([ˈɛtət kot], 'this cat'))

qas.question: What is the only minimal pair that shows g is a separate phoneme?

plausible_answers.text: that the center of the tongue is raised during and after the articulation of the consonant

qas.question: What does the tongue produce with g and x?

context: Russian is notable for its distinction based on palatalization of most of the consonants. While /k/, /ɡ/, /x/ do have palatalized allophones [kʲ, ɡʲ, xʲ], only /kʲ/ might be considered <a0_0><b3_0>a phoneme<b3_0/><a0_0/>, though it is marginal and generally not considered <b4_0>distinctive<b4_0/> (the only native minimal pair which argues for /kʲ/ to be a separate phoneme is <b5_0>"это ткёт" ([ˈɛtə tkʲɵt], 'it weaves')/"этот кот" ([ˈɛtət kot], 'this cat'))<b5_0/>. Palatalization means <b6_0>that <a1_0>the center of the tongue is raised during and after the articulation of the consonant<b6_0/><a1_0/>. In the case of /tʲ/ and /dʲ/, the tongue is raised enough to produce <b7_0>slight frication (affricate sounds)<b7_0/>. These sounds: /t, d, ts, s, z, n and rʲ/ are dental, that is pronounced <a2_0>with the tip of the tongue against the teeth rather than against the alveolar ridge<a2_0/>.
